Classes & Value Types

Emojicode features three kind of types that feature characteristics of object- orientation: Classes, Value Types and Enumerations. This chapter is soley dedicated to classes and value types. A separate chapter is devoted to enumerations, which have a lot in common with value types.

Object-orientation can be a very broad term, but can be summarized to four concepts:

  • Dynamic lookup: An object on which a method is called dynamically executes its method. This allows inheritance and overriding methods in classes.
  • Abstraction: The implementation details are hidden and a set of public methods is provided that can manipulate that hidden data.
  • Subtyping means that if an object has all of the functionality of a given type b it can be used in the context of type b. Emojicode accomplishes this using protocols.
  • Inheritance is the ability to reuse the definition of one type for another.

It should be noted that only classes take advantage of all concepts above, while value types and enumerations only provide abstraction and subtyping.

Classes versus Value Types

There are significant differences between classes and value types:

  • Instances of classes are always allocated on the heap and are passed by reference. Instances of value types are, as their name suggests, passed by value.
  • Classes feature inheritance while value types donâ€™t.
  • Value Type methods are statically dispatched.

This makes value types suitable when only the actual data represented matters and not the identity of the object. In other words, you should use value types when you only care about the values they carry and not about whether you have a particular instance of the value type.

Dates or mathematical vectors are good examples of types that should be value types, whereas a type representing a customer should be a class, as it does matter with which particular customer instance youâ€™re dealing, since every instance represents exactly one customer.

This is again contrary to the example of a date or a vector: You can't think of them as â€œthe one youâ€™re dealing withâ€. They are abstract ideas and only exist in our brains. You could write them on a piece of paper, but then again the piece of paper would be an instance of a class, which stores the date.

Defining a Class

The syntax to define a class is:

type-body âŸ¶ ğŸ‡ type-body-declarations ğŸ‰

type-body-declaration âŸ¶ type-body-attributes type-body-declaration-main
type-body-attributes âŸ¶ [documentation-comment] [âš ï¸] [ğŸ”] [access-level] [âœ’ï¸] [ğŸ‡] [ğŸ–] [ğŸ”‘]
type-body-declaration-main âŸ¶ declaration | method | initializer
type-body-declaration-main âŸ¶ protocol-conformance | enum-value
superclass âŸ¶ type

If you omit superclass the class doesnâ€™t have a superclass.

For example, the code below defines a class named ğŸŸ, that has no superclass.

Instance Variables

To store information in your type instances, instance variables are used. The ğŸ° syntax is used to declare an instance variable.

The example below defines a ğŸŸ class with instance variables.

ğŸ‡ ğŸŸ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ° age ğŸš‚
  ğŸ° speedInM/s ğŸš€
  ğŸ° name ğŸ¬ğŸ”¡  ğŸ‘´ Fish kept in aquariums often have names
ğŸ‰

This example defines a value type named ğŸ“† that represents a date:

ğŸ•Š ğŸ“† ğŸ‡
  ğŸ° day ğŸš‚
  ğŸ° month ğŸš‚
  ğŸ° year ğŸš‚
ğŸ‰

When a type is instantiated a scope is created in which the instance variables live. This scope is always available in methods and initializers.

Instance variables are private to the instance and cannot be accessed from outside. If you want to allow modification or access of an instance variable from outside a class or value type you have to write getters and setters. Note that instance variables are also kept private from subclasses.

Initializers

Initializers are responsible to prepare an instance for use and are called to instantiate a type, that is gaining an instance of the given type.

The syntax to define an initializer is:

initializer âŸ¶ ğŸˆ [init-error] name [init-parameters] block
init-parameters âŸ¶ init-parameter | init-parameter init-parameters
init-parameter âŸ¶ [ğŸ¼] variable type
init-error âŸ¶ ğŸš¨ type

In an initializer all instance variables must be initialized. (Remember that variables of an optional type are automatically initialized to Nothingness, which is also true for instance variables.)

Furthermore, if youâ€™re initializing a class instance whose class has a superclass you must call an initializer of the superclass . The ğŸ keyword is used to call a superinitializer:

superinitializer âŸ¶ ğŸ superinitializer [arguments]

By enforcing these rules, Emojicode can guarantee that any instance of any type is always fully initialized when obtained from the intializer.

The following example is an initializer for the ğŸŸ class:

ğŸˆ ğŸ ageGiven ğŸš‚ nameGiven ğŸ¬ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ® age ageGiven
  ğŸ® name nameGiven
  ğŸ® speedInM/s 0
ğŸ‰

This initializer initializes all variables to appropriate values. age and name were initialized to values passed by arguments. speedInM/s was set to a default value.

Value type initializers work quite similarly, with one big difference: In contrast to class initializers they return a value. This will change in a further version of Emojicode.

Initializing Instance Variables from Arguments

Because itâ€™s so common that instance variables are initialized from arguments, thereâ€™s a shortcut to this: ğŸ¼. ğŸ¼ can be used in front of the variable name of an argument and then automatically copies the value passed into the instance variable with the same name.

The example above improved with ğŸ¼:

ğŸˆ ğŸ ğŸ¼ age ğŸš‚ ğŸ¼ name ğŸ¬ğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡
  ğŸ® speedInM/s 0
ğŸ‰

Instantiation

Its syntax is:

initializer must be the name of the initializer you want to use. Naturally, you need to provide the correct number of appropriate arguments.

To get a ğŸŸ instance for example, you would use:

Methods

Methods are functionality bound to a specific type: a class or value type.

method âŸ¶ ğŸ– method-emoji [generic-arguments] [parameters] [return-type] block
parameters âŸ¶ parameter | parameter parameters

return âŸ¶ ğŸ expression

Calling Methods

The syntax to call a method is special:

method-call âŸ¶ method-emoji callee [arguments]
callee âŸ¶ expression
arguments âŸ¶ expression | expression arguments

method-emoji is the name of the method you wish to call. callee is the instance whose method should be called. Of course all arguments must be provided as required.

Letâ€™s take a look at an example using the ğŸŸ class:

ğŸ¦ michaelTheFish ğŸ”·ğŸŸğŸ 3 ğŸ”¤MichaelğŸ”¤

This Context

You often will want to get the instance on which the method was called, this is the object or the value. This is what ğŸ• is for.

ğŸ• returns the current value, whose method or initializer is being called.

Here, for instance, a method of ğŸŸ is shown, which calls another method to determine whether the fish on which the method was called should retire or can sign a new contract of employment:

ğŸ‰

Note that in an initializer, you canâ€™t use ğŸ• before the object is fully initialized, that is before all instance variables were set and the superinitializer was called. If this was allowed, you could call methods on the instance which might access instance variable that had not been initialized yet.

Type Methods

Itâ€™s possible to define type methods which are called on the type rather than on an instance of the type.

Type methods are defined like normal methods but with the ğŸ‡ attribute. As for example:

ğŸ‡ ğŸ• ğŸ‡
  ğŸŒ® Returns the available pizzas. ğŸŒ®
  ğŸ‡ğŸ– ğŸ“œ â¡ï¸ ğŸ¨ğŸšğŸ”¡ ğŸ‡

ğŸ‰

Since type methods donâ€™t execute in an object context the use of ğŸ• is illegal. Type methods are also inherited by subclasses.

Calling Type Methods

The syntax to call a type method is:

type-method-call âŸ¶ ğŸ© method-emoji type [arguments]

Example:

This calls the type method ğŸ“œ on the class ğŸ•, which we just defined above.

Assignment by Call

Assignment by Call is a way of quickly replacing the content of a variable with the result of a method call on its value. E.g.

ğŸ® counter 1
ğŸ®â• counter 1

At the end of the code snippet counter will be 2. The second line works exactly like ğŸ® counter â• counter 1.

Any method can be used in an Assignment by Call as long as it returns the type of the variable. Note that the method can take any number of arguments. The following example would print the value fries, for instance.

ğŸ® string ğŸ”¤onion french friesğŸ”¤
ğŸ®ğŸ”ª string 13 5
ğŸ˜€ string

Access Levels

Access Levels describe from which context a method, class method or initializer can be called. There are three access levels:

access-level âŸ¶ ğŸ”“ | ğŸ”’ | ğŸ”
  • ğŸ”“: The method, initializer, or class method can be accessed from everywhere.
  • ğŸ”’: The method, initializer, or class method may only be accessed within the class it was defined.
  • ğŸ”: The method, initializer, or class method may only be accessed within the class it was defined or within a class that inherits from that class.

Deprecation

From time to time methods or initializers need to be deprecated. Emojicode allows you to mark a method or initializer as deprecated with the âš ï¸ attribute.

The compiler will emit a warning wherever a deprecated method or initializer is used.

Identity Check

ğŸ˜œ can be used to determine whether two objects references point to the same object in memory.

This isnâ€™t an equality check: Two objects might represents the same value but they are still two different object not sharing the same memory location. To determine equality use ğŸ˜› if available.

identity-check âŸ¶ ğŸ˜œ expression expression

ğŸ˜œ returns true if the result of both expression are references to the same memory location. Naturally, the expressionsâ€™ results must be compatible to ğŸ”µ.
